awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Jackson Morrow is "A New Approach to Lang's Conjectures via Non-Archimedean Methods." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Paul Vojta.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main outcomes of this grant was significant progress on the Demailly--Lang conjecture.  Roughly speaking, Lang's conjecture predicts that a random system of polynomial equations with rational coefficients will not have too many rational points. (Of course, there are precise meanings of "random" and "too many", but this is the general philosophy.) For curves (i.e., single polynomial equations in two variables x and y), the notion of random can be encoded in the degree of the equation (i.e., the highest power of x and y appearing in the equation), and random refers to the degree of the curve being sufficiently large. More precisely, the degree of the equation tells us about a topological invariant of a curve called the genus, and the genus of a curve governs the behavior of rational points. If the curve has genus g < 2, then the rational points on the curve are infinite (after potentially extending the rational numbers to a finite extension). If the curve has genus g > 1, then a famous result of Faltings asserts that the rational points on the curve are finite over any number field. The deep conjecture of Lang posits that the rational points on a variety of general type will not be Zariski dense. (In the setting of curves, general type is equivalent to g > 1 and not Zariski dense is equivalent to finite.) Since understanding the arithmetic properties of varieties is difficult, we seek other, more geometric ways to describe being of general type. There are conjectural complex and non-Archimedean analytic characterizations of being of general type due to Green--Griffiths, Javanpeykar, Vojta, and the PI. In the algebraic setting, we have Demailly's conjecture which says that when every sub-variety of a variety is of general type, there is a uniform bound on the complexity of curves inside of the variety, which depends on the ambient variety and is linear in the genus of the curve. 


The major outcome of this grant was a paper --- which remains under review --- where the PI proves that when every sub-variety of a variety is of general type, there is a uniform bound on the complexity of curves inside of the variety, which depends on the ambient variety and the genus of the curve. The difference between this result and Demailly's conjecture is the dependency of the genus in the bound. Previously, such results were only know in special cases (e.g., the case of hypersurfaces or closed sub-varieties of abelian varieties), and so this result represents the first signifcant progress towards Demailly's conjecture in full generality. The method of proof is new and uses equi-characteristic non-Archimedean geometry in a novel way, and the PI believes this methods will have further applications. Additionally, in a joint published paper with Achenjang, the PI proved new results on integral points on higher dimensional varieties, and in a joint preprint with Howe and Wear, the PI extended previous work of his in p-adic Hodge theory in the setting of abelian varieties to arbitrary p-divisible groups. 


Finally, the PI mentored an undergraduate student in a project related to higher degree points on a family of non-hyperelliptic genus 3 curves.
